2 check-posts destroyed |casualties2=None |}} {{Campaignbox Pakistan–United States skirmishes}} {{Campaignbox US war in Afghanistan}} {{Campaignbox Waziristan}} The '''2011 NATO attack in Pakistan''' (also known as the '''Salala incident''', '''Salala attack''' or '''26/11 attacks'''{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/pakistan-yousuf-raza-gilani-nato-26-11-attacks/1/164167.html|title=Pakistan PM Gilani refers to NATO strike as '26/11 attacks'|work=India Today|date=14 December 2011|accessdate=20 November 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-6-91995-Pakistan-may-restore-Nato-supplies-on-new-terms |title=Pakistan may restore Nato supplies on new terms |work=The News |date=10 February 2012 |accessdate=20 November 2014 |first=Amir |last=Mir |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129115409/http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-6-91995-Pakistan-may-restore-Nato-supplies-on-new-terms |archivedate=29 November 2014 |df= }}), was a border skirmish that occurred when US-led [[NATO]] forces engaged [[Pakistan Army|Pakistani security forces]] at two Pakistani military checkposts along the [[Durand Line|Afghanistan–Pakistan border]] on Saturday, 26 November 2011.{{cite web|title=NATO 'Regrets' Pakistan Strike |url=http://newsweekpakistan.com/scope/612 |publisher=[[Newsweek Pakistan]] |last=Islam |first=Nazarul |date=27 November 2011 |accessdate=27 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426005053/http://newsweekpakistan.com/scope/612 |archivedate=26 April 2012 |df= }} Two NATO [[Apache helicopters]]{{cite news|title=Anger as NATO copters kill 24 Pakistani soldiers|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article2662246.ece|work=The Hindu |location=India|last=Joshua|first=Anita|date=26 November 2011|accessdate=28 November 2011}}{{cite web|title=NATO came under fire from Pakistan before attack: sources |url=https://news.yahoo.com/nato-came-under-fire-pakistan-attack-sources-134017538.html |publisher=[[Yahoo! News]] |author=[[Reuters]] |date=27 November 2011 |accessdate=28 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223144508/http://news.yahoo.com/nato-came-under-fire-pakistan-attack-sources-134017538.html |archivedate=23 December 2011 |df=dmy }} an [[AC-130 gunship]] and two [[McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle|F-15E Eagle]] fighter jets entered by varying estimates as little as 200 meters{{cite web|title=Namaz-e-Janaza of Salala soldiers offered in Peshawar |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=10598&Cat=13 |author=Mushtaq Yusufzai|publisher=The International News, Karachi|date=28 November 2011|accessdate=28 November 2011}} (660 ft) to up to 2.5 kilometres (1.6 miles),{{cite news|title=Pakistan buries 24 troops killed in NATO airstrike|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-15908760|publisher=BBC News |date=26 November 2011|accessdate=27 November 2011}} into the Pakistani border area of [[Salala, Pakistan|Salala]] (in the [[Baizai]] subdivision of [[Mohmand Agency]], [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas|FATA]]) at 2 a.m. local time.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-11-26/pakistan/30443897_1_taliban-militants-pakistani-soldiers-pakistani-troops|title=28 Pakistani troops killed in NATO attack, outrage in Islamabad|work=Times of India|date=26 November 2011|accessdate=3 December 2011}} {{Dead link|date=February 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} They came from across the border in [[Afghanistan]] and opened fire at two border patrol check-posts, killing 28 Pakistani soldiers{{cite news|title=Pakistan halts Nato supplies after attack leaves soldiers dead|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/26/pakistan-halts-nato-supplies-attack|work=The Guardian |location=UK|last=Coleman|first=Jasmine|date=26 November 2011|accessdate=27 November 2011}} and wounding 12 others. The two Pakistan Army check-posts were codenamed "Boulder" and "Volcano" respectively. This attack resulted in a deterioration of relations between Pakistan and the United States. The Pakistani public reacted with protests all over the country and the government took measures adversely affecting the [[US exit strategy from Afghanistan]], including the evacuation of [[Shamsi Airfield]] and closure of the [[NATO supply lines to Afghanistan|NATO supply line]]. On 3 July 2012, US Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] officially apologized for the losses suffered by the Pakistani military. Subsequently, Pakistan restored the NATO supply routes.{{cite news|author=CNN Wire Staff|title=Pakistan reopens NATO supply routes to Afghanistan|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/03/world/asia/us-pakistan-border-routes/index.html?hpt=hp_t1|work=CNN Wirestaff|publisher=CNN|accessdate=4 July 2012|date=4 July 2012}} ==Background and timeline== {{main|War in Afghanistan (2001–14)|War in North-West Pakistan}} ===The attack=== On 26 November 2011, US-led NATO forces opened fire on two Pakistani border check-posts near the [[Durand Line|Pakistan-Afghanistan border]]. The attack occurred at approximately 02:00 [[Pakistan Standard Time|local time]] (01:30 in Afghanistan and 21:00 [[GMT]]). According to the Director General of Military Operations (DGMO), [[Major General]] [[Ashfaq Nadeem]], the attack was a coordinated NATO strike and used two [[Boeing AH-64 Apache|AH-64D Apache Longbow]] helicopters, an [[Lockheed AC-130|AC-130H Spectre gunship]] and two [[McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle|F-15E Eagle]] fighter jets. A [[Beechcraft C-12 Huron|MC-12W Liberty]] turbo-propeller aircraft was used in an [[ISTAR|intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance]] role.{{cite web|title=US Central Command Investigation into Salala Checkpoint Engagement|url=https://www.scribd.com/full/80616338?access_key=key-26rt0xtpw7icq41c5zat|accessdate=6 February 2012}} The check-posts were located {{convert|200|m}} to {{convert|2.5|km}} inside Pakistan from the border with Afghanistan in the Salala area of the Baizai subdivision of the [[Mohmand Agency]] in the [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]] (FATA), Pakistan, and separated by a distance of one kilometre on the Salala mountain top. The attacks caused the deaths of up to twenty-four Pakistani soldiers, including two officers, Major Mujahid Mirani and [[Captain (OF-2)|Captain]] Usman Ali. Thirteen other soldiers were injured.{{cite web |author=Web18 |url=http://www.firstpost.com/world/pakistan-cuts-nato-supply-lines-after-unprovoked-attack-141140.html |title=Pakistan cuts NATO supply lines after 'unprovoked' attack |publisher=Firstpost |accessdate=29 November 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/NewsDetail.aspx?ID=27328&title=Pakistan-protest-Nato-attack-on-check-post |title=Pakistan protest NATO attack on check post |publisher=[[The News International]] |accessdate=29 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111127011820/http://www.thenews.com.pk/NewsDetail.aspx?ID=27328&title=Pakistan-protest-NATO-attack-on-check-post |archivedate=27 November 2011 |df=dmy }}{{cite web |url=http://radio.gov.pk/newsdetail-12599 |title=Radio Pakistan – At least twenty-five security officials including two officers were martyred when the NATO helicopters... |publisher=[[Pakistan Broadcasting Corporation|Radio Pakistan]] |accessdate=29 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426002531/http://radio.gov.pk/newsdetail-12599 |archivedate=26 April 2012 |df=dmy }} Both sides reported they were attacked first. The poorly defined border, as well as a history of [[Taliban insurgency|Taliban fighters]] moving around the Afghan border regions, were cited as possible contributing factors to the incident. [[File:AC-130H Spectre (2152981898).jpg|thumb|An AC-130 gunship (pictured) was used in addition to two Apache helicopters and two F-15E Eagle fighter jets to carry out the attack.]] ====US-Afghan claims==== According to Afghan and US officials, the incident started after US-Afghan coalition forces, which were conducting an operation against the Afghan Taliban in Afghanistan's eastern [[Kunar Province]], were fired upon from border positions within Pakistan.[https://news.yahoo.com/nato-came-under-fire-pakistan-attack-sources-134017538.html NATO came under fire from Pakistan before attack: sources] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223144508/http://news.yahoo.com/nato-came-under-fire-pakistan-attack-sources-134017538.html |date=23 December 2011 }}, Reuters, 27 November 2011 "There was firing coming from the position against Afghan army soldiers who requested support", said one Afghan official in Kabul. The Afghan official further stated they were being fired upon directly from a Pakistani military outpost itself.{{cite web|last=Shrivastava|first=Sanskar;|title=US, NATO Attack on Pakistan Affected South Asia's Geopolitics Over a Week|url=http://www.theworldreporter.com/2011/11/us-nato-attack-on-pakistan-affected.html|work=The World Reporter|accessdate=30 November 2011}} A Western official backed up that view by stating, "They were fired on from a Pakistani army base." And, "It was a defensive action." According to Afghan and US accounts helicopters were then called in for support against the incoming fire.{{cite news|last=Nissenbaum|first=Dion; Tom Wright; Adam Entous|title=Airstrike Ravages U.S.-Pakistan Ties|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204630904577061270317324992|work=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=28 November 2011|date=28 November 2011}}[https://news.yahoo.com/afghan-soldiers-called-deadly-nato-airstrike-143342422.html Afghan soldiers called in deadly NATO airstrike], AP, RAHIM FAIEZ and RIAZ KHAN, 27 November 2011{{cite web|last=Flaherty |first=Anne |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/nov/27/2-key-senators-call-tough-line-pakistan/ |title=2 key senators call for tough line with Pakistan |work=Washington Times |accessdate=29 November 2011}} A Pakistani defence official reportedly admitted that soldiers in the Pakistani border post sitting there for the express purpose of stopping infiltration fired a few flares, a couple of mortar rounds and one or two bursts of machine-gun fire in that direction.{{cite news|title=Afghans say commando unit was attacked before airstrike was called on Pakistan|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/afghans-say-unit-was-attacked-before-airstrike/2011/11/28/gIQAX6ZY5N_story.html?hpid=z1|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=Washington Post|author=Karen DeYoung|author2=Joshua Partlow|date=29 November 2011}} Another US official in Kabul pointed to [[Pakistan–United States skirmishes#Kurram incident|an incident in September 2010]], when a NATO helicopter fired on a Pakistan outpost, killing two soldiers. "It was a situation where insurgent forces butted right up against a Pakistani border post and used that as a firing position. When we fired back, we hit Pakistani security forces. Military officials in Kabul claimed insurgents in Pakistan have also used empty Pakistan border bases to stage attacks, which they say may have been the working assumption of the coalition forces who called in the airstrike when they drew fire. One US official said NATO forces had informed the Pakistani army's 11th Corps command near the western border that operations against Taliban insurgents would take place on that day. Pakistani General Abbas admitted in a press conference that coalition forces had "informed our military earlier, much earlier, that they will be conducting an operation there." According to the US military, information about the proposed strike was passed on at one of the centres on the border where both sides station officers and exchange information in an effort to avoid firing on each other, after which Pakistani officers cleared the strike, saying that there were no Pakistani forces in the area.Barnes, Julian E. and Adam Entous, "[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203833104577072771910500442?mod=googlenews_wsj Pakistan Was Consulted Before Fatal Hit, U.S. Says]", ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', 2 December 2011.[[Bill Roggio|Roggio, Bill]], "[http://www.longwarjournal.org/threat-matrix/archives/2011/12/pakistan_cleared_isaf_airstrik.php Pakistan cleared ISAF airstrikes that killed its own troops], ''[[Long War Journal]]'', 2 December 2011. ====Pakistani claims==== [[Image:FATA (8).png|thumb|border|right|alt=A map showing parts of Pakistan and Afghanistan, including the Federally Administered Tribal Areas that are located in Pakistan, adjacent to the south-east border of Afghanistan.|Map of the [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]] (in colours) of Pakistan. The [[Mohmand Agency]] is located in the north. Click to enlarge]] The incident sparked outrage and controversy in Pakistan, which termed the attack an "unprovoked and indiscriminate firing,"{{cite news|title=Pakistan blasts "unprovoked" NATO attacks|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-57331477-503543/pakistan-blasts-unprovoked-nato-attacks/|publisher=[[CBS News]]}} an "irresponsible act," and a "stark violation" of its sovereignty. Leaders of the Pakistani military establishment viewed NATO's attacks on the army checkposts as intentional, pre-planned and premeditated.{{cite news|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/national/28-Dec-2011/pakistan-rejects-us-army-findings-on-nato-attacks|title=Pakistan rejects US army findings on Nato attacks|work=The Nation|date=28 December 2011|accessdate=16 February 2012}} Slamming NATO's version of events as "lame excuses", Pakistan rejected claims of any firing having emanated from its side as a prelude to the encounter, saying that the soldiers who were manning the post were asleep and resting when NATO launched the assault at night.{{cite news|author=5 Minutes 10 Minutes |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/pakistan-hits-lame-excuses-for-nato-attack/story-e6frg6so-1226208563639 |title=Pakistan hits 'lame excuses' for NATO attack |work=The Australian |accessdate=29 November 2011 |date=29 November 2011}} The director general of the [[Inter Services Public Relations|ISPR]], [[Major General]] [[Athar Abbas]] challenged NATO to "present proof if they claim that firing was started from Pakistani side. No fire was opened from our side."{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/11/29/nato-attack-govt-response-leaves-room-for-fence-mending.html|title=Nato attack: Govt response leaves room for fence-mending|work=Dawn News|date=28 November 2011|accessdate=30 November 2011}} He asserted that "At this point, NATO and Afghanistan are trying to wriggle out of the situation by offering excuses. Where are their casualties?"{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/pakistan-says-nato-ignored-pleas-during-attack-074025755.html|title=Pakistan says NATO ignored its pleas during attack|work=Yahoo! News|date=28 November 2011|accessdate=16 February 2012}} Meanwhile, the claim that the airstrike was cleared by Pakistani authorities was categorically denied by Pakistan{{cite news|title=Pakistan denies firing provoked Nato border attack|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-15915247|newspaper=BBC|date=28 November 2011}}{{cite news|title=Pakistan allows army to counter-attack Nato|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/world/pakistan-allows-army-to-counter-attack-nato-2011-12-02-1.431083|newspaper=Reuters|date=2 December 2011}} which claimed that the attack continued for two hours, even after Pakistani officials alerted coalition forces to stop.{{cite news|title=Afghans say commando unit was attacked before airstrike was called on Pakistan|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/afghans-say-unit-was-attacked-before-airstrike/2011/11/28/gIQAX6ZY5N_story.html?hpid=z1|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=Washington Post|author=Karen DeYoung|author2=Joshua Partlow|quote="''.....That account of the mission is disputed by Pakistani authorities, who say the U.S. launched an unprovoked attack on two of their border posts, a prolonged assault that continued for nearly two hours including after Pakistani officials alerted the coalition forces to stop''"|date=29 November 2011}} Preliminary reports from the [[Pakistan Army]] told of about 40 soldiers being present at the two check posts, most of whom were sleeping or resting when the raid took place.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-15901363 |title=Pakistan outrage after 'Nato attack kills soldiers' |publisher=BBC News |last1=Childs |first1=Nick |date=12 May 2011 |accessdate=29 November 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/297979/nato-jets-attack-checkpost-on-pak-afghan-border/ |title=24 soldiers killed in NATO attack on Pakistan checkpost |publisher=[[The Express Tribune]] |date=26 November 2011}} The helicopters first attacked the border post, named "Volcano", atop the mountain peak. This initial attack cut all the communications to and from the post, and a [[Pakistan Air Force]] air support could not be called in time to counter the attack.{{cite web |title=Not interested: Islamabad rejects NATO joint probe |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/301511/not-interested-islamabad-rejects-nato-joint-probe/ |publisher=[[The Express Tribune]] |last1=Khan |first1=Zia |date=3 December 2011 |accessdate=3 December 2011}} Instead, Pakistani troops stationed at the nearby post named "Boulder" engaged the NATO helicopters with [[Anti-aircraft warfare|anti-aircraft guns]]. The helicopters soon withdrew. Pakistani authorities tried to contact their NATO counterparts in an effort to inform them of the situation but the Pakistani request reportedly failed to reach the attacking force. The helicopters returned a second time engaging Boulder border post again. A short while later communication with the NATO commanders was established and the attack was called off. All casualties were from the initial attack on the Volcano border post. Later, Major General Abbas expressed that it was beyond comprehension why the NATO forces returned to attack the second time.{{cite web |title=Salala post attack beyond comprehension: ISPR |url=http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Politics/03-Dec-2011/Salala-post-attack-beyond-comprehension-ISPR |publisher=[[The Nation (Pakistani newspaper)|The Nation]] |date=3 December 2011 |accessdate=3 December 2011}} According to local officials, there was no militant activity along the Afghan border region when NATO conducted the attack. Abbas, spokesperson ISPR, said that the coordinates of the two border posts had been given to ISAF. He added that the attack lasted for almost two hours and claimed that the personnel on the posts alerted the GHQ which in turn immediately informed the ISAF regional base in Afghanistan to stop the attack at roughly 12:30 AM{{cite news|last=KIMBERLY DOZIER|title=US suspects NATO forces lured into deadly raid|url=https://news.yahoo.com/us-suspects-nato-forces-lured-deadly-raid-071123118.html|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=29 November 2011}} but they did not.{{cite news|last=CHRIS BRUMMITT|title=Pakistan says NATO ignored its pleas during attack|url=http://arabnews.com/world/article539771.ece|newspaper=Arab News|date=28 November 2011}} GHQ in return gave permission to the personnel on the outposts to retaliate. NATO communicated at roughly 1:15 AM that they had realised that they were attacking Pakistan Army and that their forces had been ordered to stop. Yet NATO's aerial bombardment continued with another salvo aiming at the Pakistani rescue force that rushed to the aid of the two posts. Pakistan termed the event an "unprovoked and indiscriminate firing", an "irresponsible act",{{cite news|title=Afghans Say Pakistan Fired First in NATO Attack|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204630904577061270317324992|work=The Wall Street Journal|last1=Tom|first1=Wright|last2=Nissenbaum|first2=Dion|date=27 November 2011|accessdate=27 November 2011}} and a "stark violation" of its sovereignty.{{cite web|url=http://english.kyodonews.jp/news/2011/11/128393.html |title=Pakistan condemns NATO attack as 'stark violation' of sovereignty |publisher=English.kyodonews.jp |date=23 November 2011 |accessdate=29 November 2011}} The attack was the deadliest NATO strike on Pakistani soil since the start of the war in Afghanistan.{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/16118154 |title=Pakistan Deaths: US Offers Condolences |publisher=News.sky.com |accessdate=29 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128231518/http://news.sky.com/home/world-news/article/16118154 |archivedate=28 November 2011 |df= }} In a media conference with the Director General of Military Operations (DGMO) Major General Ashfaq, Chief of General Staff [[Lieutenant General]] [[Waheed Arshad]], claimed that this was not an "unintended" incident. On accounts of series of events he commented that NATO was informed at the time of attack but their helicopters remained on course of aggression. Pakistani military also said that the NATO forces returned a second time to attack the post again. When he was asked whether Pakistan was satisfied with the investigating team headed under US Air force [[Brigadier General]] Stephon, he responded sharply by commenting that all incidents in past in relation to violation of Pakistan's sovereignty did not come to an agreeable conclusion. Pakistan was invited to jointly investigate the incident, but Pakistan refused to participate.Matthew Rosenberg and Eric Schmitt, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/03/world/asia/pakistan-refuses-to-help-as-us-sorts-out-fatal-airstrikes.html Pakistan Refuses to Help as U.S. Sorts Out a Fatal Attack] ''[[New York Times]]'' 2 December 2011 On 9 December, Major General Ashfaq claimed that NATO had been monitoring radio transmissions that night and knew they had hit Volcano post.{{cite news|title=Pakistan to deploy air defence weapons on Afghan border|url=http://www.firstpost.com/fwire/pakistan-to-deploy-air-defence-weapons-on-afghan-border-151844.html|publisher=First Post |date=9 December 2011}}{{cite news|title=Pak to deploy air defence weapons on Afghan border|publisher=rediff News |author=Rezaul H Laskar |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/pak-to-deploy-air-defence-weapons-on-afghan-border1/20111209.htm|date=9 December 2011}} The Pakistani military called the strike "unprovoked and indiscriminate." Government of Pakistan launched a strong protest with U.S and also immediately discontinued the supply to NATO troops located in Afghanistan. Notably, the strike on Saturday came one day after Gen. John Allen, the commander of the US-led coalition in Afghanistan, visited Pakistani army chief Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani. In that meeting, both the commanders discussed border co-ordination and other measures "aimed at enhancing border control on both sides." ==Repercussions of the incident== ===Closure of NATO supply lines=== {{Main|NATO supply lines to Afghanistan}} [[File:NATO supply routes through Pakistan.svg|thumb|NATO supply lines through Pakistan]] Pakistan immediately closed all [[NATO supply lines to Afghanistan|NATO supplies to Afghanistan]] in the aftermath of the attack,{{cite web|last=Shakeel Anjum|title=Supply line permanently stopped: Malik|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=10583&Cat=13|accessdate=28 November 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/297991/pakistan-blocks-afghanistan-nato-supplies-after-checkpost-attack/|title=Pakistan blocks Afghanistan NATO supplies after check-post attack|work=Express Tribune|date=26 November 2011|accessdate=26 November 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/11/26/world/asia/pakistan-nato-attack/index.html |title=Pakistan to review relations with U.S., NATO, ISAF in wake of attack |publisher=CNN |accessdate=29 November 2011 |date=27 November 2011}} leaving the blockaded supply trucks vulnerable to attacks.{{cite news|title=Pakistan retaliation puts NATO in lurch|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57331648/pakistan-retaliation-puts-nato-in-lurch/?tag=stack|work=CBS News|accessdate=27 November 2011}} NATO trucks had been using the supply routes, in [[Khyber Agency]] (through the [[Khyber Pass]] at [[Torkham]]) and [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]] (near [[Chaman]]), to supply US and international forces fighting in Afghanistan.{{cite news | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/26/world/meast/pakistan-attack/index.html | title=Pakistan official: NATO attack kills 26 Pakistani soldiers | publisher=CNN | work=Nick Paton Walsh | accessdate=30 November 2011 | date=26 November 2011}} US policy makers tried to find alternative routes through Russia, [[Kazakhstan]], [[Uzbekistan]], and [[Tajikistan]] (termed as the "Northern Distribution Network") but these are longer and less effective than routes through Pakistan. Huge costs are associated with the Central Asian supply lines, and NATO's supply line through Russia is already under a looming danger of closure due to friction over missile defence plans.{{cite news|last=Abdul Zahoor Khan Marwat|title=Sustainability of Nato supply line|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=81604&Cat=2|newspaper=The News|date=10 December 2011}} Being a landlocked country, Afghanistan is highly dependent on Pakistan for its imports. According to figures released by [[The Pentagon]] in January 2012, the United States was paying six times more to send supplies to troops in Afghanistan via alternative supply routes following the closure of Pakistani routes. The figures placed the new US costs at $104 million per month, roughly $87 million costlier per month than when the cargo was transported via Pakistan.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/10049831|title=APNewsBreak: Costs soar for new war supply routes|newspaper=The Guardian|date=19 January 2012|accessdate=24 February 2012|author=Robert Burns|location=London}} The high costs were associated with the routes being lengthier. ====Continued strife==== In late March 2012, a US military official stated that the United States would have to use routes through the Northern Distribution Network (NDN) for supplies to Afghanistan if Pakistan refused to reopen its supply lines. However, he conceded the expensiveness of these routes and noted that negotiations with Pakistan regarding the possibility of opening of the supply routes were ongoing.{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/357443/us-to-rely-on-india-in-case-pakistan-doesnt-resume-nato-routes/|title='US to rely on India in case Pakistan doesn't resume NATO routes'|work=Express Tribune|last=Imtiaz|first=Huma|date=30 March 2012|accessdate=30 March 2012}} After reviewing United States-Pakistan relations and outlining what was needed to repair bilateral relations, the Pakistani parliament turned the decision of reopening the NATO supply lines over to the government in April 2012.{{cite news|last=Latif|first=Aamir|title=Pakistan moves to reopen NATO supply lines, but US ties remain frayed|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-South-Central/2012/0416/Pakistan-moves-to-reopen-NATO-supply-lines-but-US-ties-remain-frayed|accessdate=22 April 2012|newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor|date=16 April 2012}} Due to an [[Pakistani general election, 2013|upcoming general election]] in Pakistan, with widespread anti-American sentiments in the country, the Pakistani government was reluctant to reopen the lines,{{cite news|title=Talks with US on ties next week|url=http://dawn.com/2012/04/22/talks-with-us-on-ties-next-week/|accessdate=22 April 2012|newspaper=Dawn|date=22 April 2012|author=Anwar Iqbal}} and postponed its decision until the United States responded positively to Pakistani demands outlined in the parliamentary recommendations, such as a US apology for the November 2011 incident, the bringing of those involved in the strike to justice, and a stop to US drone airstrikes.{{cite web|title=Pakistan postpones reopening of NATO supply line |url=http://www.irna.ir/News/Politic/Pakistan-postpones-reopening-of-NATO-supply-line/80085125 |work=Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) |publisher=Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) |accessdate=22 April 2012 |date=18 April 2012 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Talks between Pakistan and the United States failed in April 2012 after Pakistan could not get an unconditional apology from the United States for the November 2011 incident.{{cite news|title=United States Talks Fail as Pakistanis Seek Apology|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/28/world/asia/talks-between-us-and-pakistan-fail-over-airstrike-apology.html?hp|accessdate=28 April 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=27 April 2012|author=Declan Walsh, Eric Schmitt and Steven Lee Myers}} The [[White House]] refused to apologise after [[April 2012 Afghanistan attacks|Taliban attacks in Kabul and other cities]] in Afghanistan on 15 April 2012, which according to US military and intelligence officials came from the [[Haqqani network]], an Afghan group working from a base in [[North Waziristan]] along the Afghanistan border in Pakistan's tribal belt. Pakistani officials said they cannot open the NATO supply routes in Afghanistan without a US apology.{{cite news|title=U.S. drone strikes resume in Pakistan; action may complicate vital negotiations|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/us-drone-strikes-resume-in-pakistan-action-may-complicate-vital-negotiations/2012/04/29/gIQAIprqpT_story.html?tid=pm_world_pop|accessdate=30 April 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=29 April 2012|author=Richard Leiby and Karen DeYoung}} Later in May, Pakistan demanded the United States to pay stiff fees as a condition to open up NATO supply routes into Afghanistan. The United States, however, could not pay the required $5,000 per truck due to budgetary restraints according to US Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta.{{cite news|title=U.S. bristles at stiff Pakistani fees for supply routes|url=http://security.blogs.cnn.com/2012/05/19/u-s-bristles-at-stiff-pakistani-fees-for-supply-routes/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=19 May 2012|author=Mike Mount and Elise Labott|date=19 May 2012}}{{cite news|title=U.S., Pakistan fail to reach deal on supply routes ahead of NATO summit|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/05/19/world/obama-g8-nato/index.html?hpt=wo_c2|work=Mike Mount and Elise Labott|publisher=CNN|accessdate=20 May 2012|date=19 May 2012}}{{cite news|title=NATO Summit Opens With No Deal on Pakistan Supply Lines|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/21/world/asia/pakistan-supply-lines-an-issue-during-nato-summit.html?ref=northatlantictreatyorganization|accessdate=21 May 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=20 May 2012|author=Matthew Rosenberg, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper}} "Considering the financial challenges that we're facing, that's not likely," Panetta said of the Pakistani demand of $5,000 for each truck carrying supplies across its territory for NATO troops waging the Afghanistan war.{{cite news|title=Panetta to confront Pakistan at NATO summit on transport costs|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-panetta-interview-20120519,0,2864210.story|accessdate=7 July 2012|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=19 May 2012|author=David S. Cloud}} Unnamed US officials said that US officials said they had hoped a meeting between Pakistani President [[Asif Ali Zardari]] and US President Barack Obama as well as sharing the spotlight with President Obama and other global leaders during the [[2012 Chicago Summit|2012 NATO Chicago Summit]] might provide an incentive for a deal on resuming supply shipments. "The invitation was an inducement to get them back into the international fold," said a senior US official, speaking anonymously because of the sensitive issues. "But the Pakistanis couldn't get their own act together" in time for the summit. "The main issue, it seems, is money."{{cite news|title=NATO summit: Obama's Pakistan gamble falls flat|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-nato-afghanistan-20120522,0,3468909,full.story|accessdate=7 July 2012|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=21 May 2012|author=David S. Cloud and Kathleen Hennessey}} The United States and Pakistan had nearly completed a deal to reopen crucial NATO supply routes into Afghanistan in June 2012, when Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said the US was "reaching the limits of our patience" over Islamabad's failure to root out Afghan insurgents in its tribal areas. In the wake of Panetta's comments, deputy assistant secretary of Defense Peter Lavoy was not allowed to meet with the Pakistani Army Chief, General [[Ashfaq Parvez Kayani]], and the Pentagon announced that it was bringing home a negotiating team that had worked in the Pakistani capital for nearly two months to end the bitter impasse over the supply routes. A senior US official disputed the notion that Panetta's criticism of Pakistan had set back the talks. "The sticking point for a long time has been the apology issue," the official said.{{cite news|title=Defense Secretary Panetta's Pakistan comments complicate talks|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-pakistan-talks-20120613,0,7893198.story|accessdate=8 July 2012|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=12 June 2012|author=David S. Cloud and Alex Rodriguez}} ====Supply lines reopening==== Pakistan decided to reopen the supply lines after the US Secretary of State apologised on 3 July 2012 for the Salala incident via a telephone call to Pakistani Foreign Minister Hina Rabbani Khar.{{cite news|title=Pakistan to reopen supply lines to Nato Afghan forces|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-18691691|publisher=BBC News Asia|accessdate=4 July 2012|date=3 July 2012}}{{cite news|last=Guerin|first=Orla|title=Pakistan reopens vital lines into Afghanistan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-18700001|publisher=BBC News Asia|accessdate=4 July 2012|date=3 July 2012}}{{cite web|title=Pakistan to reopen NATO supply route|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eRcI0iriH8U|work=Al Jazeera English|publisher=Youtube|accessdate=5 July 2012|date=3 July 2012}} "[[Hina Rabbani Khar|Foreign Minister Khar]] and I acknowledged the mistakes that resulted in the loss of Pakistani military lives," Clinton said in a statement.{{cite web|author=[[Hillary Clinton]]|title=Statement by Secretary Clinton on her Call With Pakistani Foreign Minister Khar (Press Release Number (PRN) 2012/1084)|url=https://www.state.gov/secretary/rm/2012/07/194502.htm|publisher=United States Department of State|date=3 July 2012|accessdate=4 July 2012}} "We are sorry for the losses suffered by the Pakistani military. We are committed to working closely with Pakistan and Afghanistan to prevent this from ever happening again." US Secretary of Defence Leon Panetta said in a separate statement that the US "remains committed to improving our partnership with Pakistan and to working closely together as our two nations confront common security challenges in the region",{{cite web|title=Pakistan to reopen NATO supply route|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2012/07/20127317715654310.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=4 July 2012|date=4 July 2012}} US General [[John R. Allen]] said in a statement that the agreement is "a demonstration of Pakistan's desire to help secure a brighter future for both Afghanistan and the region at large." and NATO Secretary-General Anders Fogh Rasmussen welcomed the announcement to reopen the supply lines, stating saying it highlighted the important role Pakistan has in supporting a stable future for Afghanistan. Pakistani reactions to the US apology were different. "We appreciate Secretary Clinton's statement, and hope that bilateral ties can move to a better place from here. I am confident that both countries can agree on many critical issues, especially on bringing peace to the region," Pakistan's ambassador to the US Sherry Rehman said in a statement. In general the decision to reopen the supply routes was met in Pakistan with a general sense of befuddlement and muted criticism that the Pakistani government had given up a much-trumpeted increase in transit fees for NATO trucks. Opposition politicians criticised the move and demanded more of an explanation from the Pakistani government and military. "Now government should let the people know about the terms and conditions for reopening the NATO supply lines. What were the demands?" said former foreign minister Shah Mehmood Qureshi. And Enver Baig, an opposition politician belonging to the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz complained about Americans: "They did not apologize. They said ‘sorry.’" Some Pakistani vowed civil disobedience to stop the convoys. "The decision to reopen NATO supplies is a big crime against the country, and we will not sit silently over this," retired Lt. Gen. Hamid Gul, a leader of the Defense Council of Pakistan (a coalition of Islamic parties that includes pro-Taliban clerics and other foes of the NATO routes) and a former chief of the Inter-Services Intelligence agency, told the Pakistani cable channel Express News. "We will come to roads and streets and protest against the decision and will also try to stop the supplies." Pakistani Taliban announced that they will attack any NATO supply trucks travelling along the routes.{{cite news|title=Pakistan Taliban threaten attacks after NATO supply routes deal|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/03/us-pakistan-usa-taliban-idUSBRE8620XH20120703|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=5 July 2012|author=Jibran Ahmad|date=3 July 2012}} Transporters who resume supplies will be "considered a friend of the U.S." and will face the consequences, a spokesman for the militant group said.{{cite news|title=Pakistani Taliban issue threats over reopening of NATO supply routes|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/04/world/asia/pakistan-taliban-threats/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=8 July 2012|author=[[Nasir Habib]]|date=4 July 2012}} [[Al Jazeera]]'s Kamal Hyder said that both NATO and Pakistani forces had taken into account losses in the past. "The losses, despite the fact that they have become a problem are nowhere near the levels that would cause alarm bells to ring" the correspondent said. According to his analysis it would cause a problem if "the Pakistani Taliban attack bridges or decide to take these people head on in the tribal areas" connecting Pakistan to the southern Afghan province of Kandahar. American officials said according to the New York Times that Hillary Clinton's increasingly cordial relationship with the young Pakistani foreign minister Hina Rabbani Khar paid dividends in resolving the dispute between both countries over the Salala incident. A final agreement on the wording of Clinton's statement of her conversation with Khar came after a week of marathon talks that included two trips to [[Islamabad]] by General [[John R. Allen]], the US commander in Afghanistan, and a quickly arranged weekend trip by [[Thomas R. Nides]], the deputy secretary of state for management and resources. In recent weeks Nides and Pakistani Finance Minister [[Abdul Hafeez Shaikh]] had spearheaded the negotiations to reopen the supply lines.{{cite news|title=Pakistan agrees to open supply lines after U.S. apology|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/pakistan-agrees-to-open-supply-lines-after-us-apology/2012/07/03/gJQAXW60KW_story.html|accessdate=4 July 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=3 July 2012|author=Karen DeYoung and Richard Leiby}} After weeks of behind-the-scenes phone calls, e-mails and meetings between Nides and [[Abdul Hafeez Shaikh]] reached an agreement on the terms for the reopening of the NATO supply lines. Besides the US apology both sides agreed to the following: After initially demanding as much as $5,000 for each truck Pakistan dropped its insistence on a higher transit fee for each truck carrying NATO's nonlethal supplies from Pakistan into Afghanistan and agreed to keep the fee at the current rate of $250. The [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama Administration]] will ask [[U.S. Congress|Congress]] to reimburse Pakistan about $1.2 billion for costs incurred by 150,000 Pakistani troops carrying out counterinsurgency operations along the border with Afghanistan. "With the GLOCs open, we will look to pay past coalition support fund claims," Pentagon spokesman Captain John Kirby said, using a Pentagon acronym for the supply routes.{{cite news|title=U.S. welcomes reopening of Pakistan-to-Afghanistan supply route|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/07/us-welcomes-re-opening-of-supply-route-from-pakistan-to-afghanistan.html|accessdate=7 July 2012|newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=3 June 2012}} The United States military reimburses by "coalition support funds" Pakistan for logistical, military and other support provided to American military operations against militants, but these payments have been suspended since Pakistan shut off the routes. More precisely the US halted paying the bills from Pakistan as tension rose between the two countries. The Pentagon will now consult with Congress about paying the bills prior to paying Pakistan in full.{{cite news|title=First NATO trucks move into Afghanistan from Pakistan after 7-month closure|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/07/05/world/asia/pakistan-nato-routes/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=8 July 2012|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=6 July 2012}} During their telephone call Pakistani Foreign Minister Hina Rabbani Khar made it clear to Secretary of State Clinton that no lethal equipment would transit into Afghanistan through the Ground Lines of Communication i.e. the ground supply lines except those meant for equipping the [[Afghan National Security Forces]].{{cite news|last=Joshua|first=Anita|title=Pakistan to reopen NATO supply lines|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article3599355.ece|accessdate=5 July 2012|newspaper=The Hindu|date=4 July 2012|location=Islamabad}} Pakistan's Defense Committee of the Cabinet, which approved the deal, said the agreement was in the country's best interest and a boon to the Afghanistan peace process. Allowing NATO convoys to enter and exit Pakistani territory would speed the withdrawal of Western forces, the Pakistani government said in a statement, and "enable a smooth transition in Afghanistan." According to the New York Times the agreement reflected a growing realisation by Pakistani officials that they had overplayed their hand, misjudged NATO's resolve and ability to adapt to the closing by using an alternative route through Central Asia, and a recognition on both sides that the impasse risked transforming an often [[Pakistan–United States relations|rocky relationship]]{{cite news|title=Highs and lows in U.S.-Pakistan relations – The two countries are allies but their relationship has been plagued by mistrust|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/special/world/us-pakistan-timeline/|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=4 July 2012}} into a permanently toxic one at a critically inopportune time. Despite the resolving of the Salala incident there are frictions in both countries relations such as Pakistan's opposition to US [[unmanned combat air vehicle|drone strikes]] on Pakistan soil, and Washington's allegations that Islamabad condones, or even assists, anti-American militants.{{cite news|title=U.S., Pakistan reach deal to reopen Afghan supply routes|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/03/us-pakistan-usa-nato-idUSBRE8620TP20120703|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=5 July 2012|author=Andrew Quinn and Qasim Nauman|date=3 July 2012}} The deal ended a diplomatic deadlock that brought US relations with the nuclear-armed South Asian nation to a near standstill and hindered counter-terrorism operations against Pakistan-based militants. Because of the supply lines closure the United States has spent at least an additional $100 million a month{{cite news|last=DeYoung|first=Karen|title=Pakistan border closure costs U.S. $100 million a month|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/pakistan-border-closure-costs-us-100-million-a-month/2012/06/13/gJQAqhCfaV_story.html|accessdate=4 July 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=13 June 2012}} because it was instead forced to move supplies by air, rail or truck through Russia and other countries north of Afghanistan at much longer and more expensive routes.{{cite news|title=Pakistan agrees to reopen NATO supply routes after U.S. apology|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-pakistan-nato-supplies-20120704,0,3927618,full.story|accessdate=7 July 2012|newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=3 July 2012|author=Alex Rodriguez and David S. Cloud}} The closure of the supply lines complicated the American troop withdrawal from Afghanistan, cost the United States more than $1 billion in extra shipping fees as a result of having to use the alternative routes through Central Asia{{cite news|last=Schmitt|first=Eric|title=Clinton's 'Sorry' to Pakistan Ends Barrier to NATO|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/04/world/asia/pakistan-opens-afghan-routes-to-nato-after-us-apology.html?_r=2&pagewanted=all|accessdate=4 July 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 July 2012}} and also held up delivery of thousands of armoured vehicles and other equipment meant for the fledgling Afghan army and police, slowing US efforts to build Afghan forces that can stand up to the [[Taliban insurgency]] as foreign troops withdraw. The reopening of the supply lines means that the US will save hundreds of millions of dollars in the run-up to the [[2012 Chicago Summit#Afghanistan war 2|withdrawal of NATO forces from the Afghanistan]] and also that it would help the US and NATO to complete its withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan "at a much lower cost" according to Clinton. Despite the reopening of critical supply routes from Pakistan, the US military confronts a giant logistical challenge to wind down the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|war in Afghanistan]] because it must withdraw till the end of 2014 nearly 90,000 troops and enormous depots of military equipment accumulated over a decade of war which includes 100,000 shipping containers stuffed with materiel and 50,000 wheeled vehicles.{{cite news|title=Northern land routes to be crucial in U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan (Registration required)|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/northern-land-routes-to-be-crucial-in-us-withdrawal-from-afghanistan/2012/07/04/gJQAoMvONW_story.html?tid=pp_widget&wp_login_redirect=0|accessdate=4 July 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=4 July 2012|author=Craig Whitlock and Karen DeYoung}} The above-mentioned agreement between Pakistan and the United States was never an issue of money alone. "It was a matter of honor for the army," said Laiq ur-Rehman, a Pakistani defence correspondent for ARY News, a cable channel. "The only word they were looking for was 'sorry.' It was a matter of pride, a matter of honor, a matter of ego." "If it had been about the money, it would have been done months ago," said a US senior administration official knowledgeable about the negotiations. "Just like for us, it was not just about the supply routes." According to the BBC the reason for the long US refusal to apologise for the Salala incident was deep anger among Americans about the death of US soldiers in Afghanistan from attacks by militant groups with alleged connections to Pakistan's [[Inter-Services Intelligence|ISI]] intelligence agency.{{cite news|title=Man in Afghan army uniform wounds five Nato soldiers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-18701210|publisher=BBC News Asia|accessdate=4 July 2012|date=4 July 2012}} Another reason for the United States refusal to apologise was the determination by American military investigators that Pakistan was equally culpable in the Salala incident because Pakistani soldiers, stationed on a ridge overlooking the border, had fired first on US troops on the Afghan side of the border.{{cite news|last=Rodriguez|first=Alex|title=Pakistan reopens NATO supply routes to Afghanistan|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/07/pakistan-reopens-nato-supply-routes-afghanistan.html|accessdate=4 July 2012|newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=3 July 2012}} Pakistan has disputed that conclusion, saying its forces did not fire first. After the first NATO supply trucks crossed the Afghan border on 5 June 2012,{{cite news|author=Mahvish Ahmad|title=Just a 'sorry'? Pakistanis question NATO supply line deal.|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-South-Central/2012/0705/Just-a-sorry-Pakistanis-question-NATO-supply-line-deal|accessdate=8 July 2012|newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor|date=5 July 2012}} Pakistanis questioned the NATO supply line deal. "The US has not apologized formally," said Nawaz Sharif, the leader of the main opposition party Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz. Imran Khan, another major opposition figure, went further, saying that "the decision isn't only against national interest but can also stir unrest within the ranks of the armed forces." He also criticised the incumbent government as being a pawn of the United States. Political and religious parties in Pakaistan undertook "long march" to Islamabad to protest reopening of supply routes to Afghanistan.{{cite web|title=Pakistanis march against NATO supply line|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2012/07/2012781899404128.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=8 July 2012|date=8 July 2012}} Pakistan declared it will scan all NATO containers passing through the country to ensure they do not contain weapons and unapproved items will be seized.{{cite web|title=Pakistan to scan all NATO containers|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/0/47021/World/0/Pakistan-to-scan-all-NATO-containers.aspx|work=Agence France-Presse(AFP)|publisher=[[Al-Ahram]]|accessdate=13 July 2012|date=6 July 2012}} 560,000 rupees ($6,000) compensation per vehicle would be paid to the truck owners by NATO subcontractors for being out of work for seven months because of the blockade according to Rana Mohammad Aslam, vice-president of the All Pakistan Goods Carrier Association.{{cite web|title=More NATO trucks cross Afghan-Pakistan border|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/9/47524/World/International/More-NATO-trucks-cross-AfghanPakistan-border.aspx|work=Agence France-Presse (AFP)|publisher=[[Al-Ahram]]|accessdate=13 July 2012|date=12 July 2012}} === Shamsi airfield vacated === {{Main|Shamsi Airfield}} On 26 November, the same day the incident occurred, Pakistan ordered the US to shut down and vacate the [[Shamsi Airfield]] in the southwestern Balochistan province within a deadline of 15 days. US forces and the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] had reportedly leased this airbase in 2001 for joint surveillance and launching [[drone attacks in Pakistan|drone attacks]] against militants in Afghanistan and northwestern Pakistan.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18563_162-57331576/pakistan-orders-u.s-to-shut-major-down-air-base/ |title=Pakistan orders U.S. to shut major down air base |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=29 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128231146/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-18563_162-57331576/pakistan-orders-u.s-to-shut-major-down-air-base/ |archivedate=28 November 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/usdetail/212319.html |title=PressTV – Pakistan orders US vacate Shamsi drone base |publisher=Presstv.ir |date=11 December 2009 |accessdate=29 November 2011}} The Shamsi airbase was the only military base in Pakistan being used by the United States, and orders of its evacuation by US personnel symbolised an increasing rift and deterioration in relations between Pakistan and the United States. In early December, the US military personnel occupying the base, along with all military equipment, were shifted to the [[Bagram Air Base]] in Afghanistan via US military aircraft.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/12/10/fc-to-take-control-of-shamsi-base.html|title=FC to take control of Shamsi base|work=Dawn News|date=10 December 2011|accessdate=16 February 2012}} On 10 December, Pakistani troops from the [[Frontier Corps]] took full control of the airfield as scheduled, and by 11 December all remaining American staff were evacuated.{{cite news|last=AZHAR MASOOD|title='Pakistan will take over Shamsi Air Base from US on Dec. 11'|url=http://arabnews.com/world/article541169.ece|newspaper=Arabnews.com|date=30 November 2011}}{{cite news|title=Pak forces take control of Shamsi airbase|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/pak-forces-take-control-of-shamsi-airbase/210683-56.html|newspaper=IBNLive|date=10 December 2011}}{{cite news|title=FC takes control of Shamsi Airbase|url= |newspaper=The Nation|date=10 December 2011}} Upon establishing control of the airfield, the [[Flag of the United States|United States flag]] was removed from the base and replaced with the [[flag of Pakistan]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/12/11/us-personnel-vacate-shamsi-airbase.html|title=US personnel vacate Shamsi airbase|work=Dawn News|date=12 December 2011|accessdate=16 February 2012}} The impact of the closure has been questioned, as the United States still has the ability to conduct drone attacks from nearby bases in Afghanistan,{{cite news|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hGoIiTbs0vizDi0wuUuewtTwtHNA?docId=CNG.83b864429e5546a58ebb4887d6972217.3e1|title=US vacates air base in Pakistan to meet deadline|newspaper=AFP|date=11 December 2011|author=Maaz Khan|accessdate=22 December 2011}} and according to the Pakistani military, the base was used mainly for refuelling and maintenance of drones, as well as for emergency landings and logistical support, and not for conducting actual drone operations which had in fact ceased in April 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.rttnewsradio.com/Content/ArticleView.aspx?Id=1779063&CID=1&SimRec=5 |title=US Evacuates Shamsi Airbase in Pakistan |work=[[RTTNews]] |date=12 December 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811094812/http://www.rttnewsradio.com/Content/ArticleView.aspx?Id=1779063&CID=1&SimRec=5 |archivedate=11 August 2014 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/305434/us-leaving-shamsi-base-wont-have-big-impact-on-air-war/|title=US leaving Shamsi base won't have big impact on air war|date=12 December 2011|newspaper=The Express Tribune|author=Reuters|accessdate=22 December 2011}} Following the incident, Pakistan stated its intention to shoot down any future US drones intruding on its airspace,{{cite news|url=http://worldnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/12/10/9352886-pakistan-says-us-drones-in-its-air-space-will-be-shot-down |newspaper=NBC |date=10 December 2011 |accessdate=22 December 2011 |title=Pakistan says U.S. drones in its air space will be shot down |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111212032204/http://worldnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2011/12/10/9352886-pakistan-says-us-drones-in-its-air-space-will-be-shot-down |archivedate=12 December 2011 |df= }} and the US suspended drone operations to avoid antagonising Pakistan.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-21/us/30541748_1_drone-strikes-long-war-journal-north-waziristan|title=US puts brakes on drones, no attack in 33 days|newspaper=Times of India|date=21 December 2011|accessdate=22 December 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=82230&Cat=2|title=Pause in US drone attacks temporary|author=Amir Mir|date=14 December 2011|accessdate=22 December 2011|newspaper=The News}} One report said that American drone attacks in Pakistan dropped by as much as 50% due to the Salala attack, as well as legal cases.{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/316787/50-drop-in-drone-strikes-as-pak-us-ties-plunge/|title=50% drop in drone strikes as Pak-US ties plunge|work=Express Tribune|date=5 January 2011|accessdate=6 January 2011}} ===United States exit strategy=== {{See also|Withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan}} Among the immediate repercussions of the incident is that the United States' attempts to end the war in Afghanistan peacefully may now be in jeopardy. Some Pakistani officials warned that the attack could have "huge implications" for the Afghan endgame. Pakistan, which is designated as a [[major non-NATO ally]] by the United States and is seen as a key facilitator in bringing the United States to the negotiations table with the [[Taliban|Afghan Taliban]] and the [[Haqqani Network]], had already halted those efforts according to an unnamed Pakistani official close to the military establishment. While addressing a [[Senate of Pakistan|Senate]] committee, the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Hina Rabbani Khar]] warned that a repeat incident could end Pakistan's support to the United States in its war against militancy. "Enough is enough. The government will not tolerate any incident of spilling even a single drop of any civilian or soldier's blood. [[Pakistan's role in the War on Terror]] must not be overlooked." She added that "the sacrifices rendered by Pakistan in the war on terror are more than any other country. But that does not mean we will compromise on our sovereignty."{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/12/01/uk-pakistan-nato-idUKTRE7AP03W20111201|title=Enraged Pakistan says NATO attack threatens war on terror|work=Reuters|date=1 December 2011|accessdate=7 December 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/301123/nato-attack-enough-is-enough-says-hina-rabbani/ |title=NATO attack: Enough is enough, says Hina Rabbani |work=The Express Tribune |date=2 December 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65Y1JCEwK?url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/301123/nato-attack-enough-is-enough-says-hina-rabbani/ |archivedate=18 February 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} ===Pakistan's refusal to attend Bonn Conference=== {{Main|International Conference on Afghanistan, Bonn (2011)}} In the wake of the NATO attacks, the Pakistani government refused to attend the [[International Conference on Afghanistan, Bonn (2011)|Bonn conference]] scheduled on 5 December 2011. The event in [[Bonn]], Germany is an important international conference on Afghanistan.{{cite web|last=Yousaf |first=Kamran |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/298790/nato-raid-upshot-angry-pakistan-threatens-to-derail-afghan-endgame/ |title=NATO raid upshot: Angry Pakistan threatens to derail Afghan endgame |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=29 November 2011}}{{cite news|title=Pakistan Boycotts Summit After NATO Raid |first=Asif |last=Shahzad |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2100465,00.html |newspaper=Time |date=29 November 2011 |accessdate=30 November 2011}} International pressure over Pakistan amounted as it refused to attend the Bonn conference. Secretary Hillary Clinton contacted the Pakistani Prime Minister but her plea was rejected because Pakistani public opinion prohibited attendance. The conference was generally regarded as a disappointment, partially because of Pakistan's absence.{{cite news|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/column/bonn-conference-on-afghanistan-fails-to-achieve-much/20111208.htm|title=Bonn conference on Afghanistan fails to achieve much|newspaper=Rediff|author=Amir Mir|date=8 December 2011|accessdate=22 December 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2011/12/201112189190996839.html|title=A dearth of substance plagues Bonn conference|date=9 December 2011|accessdate=22 December 2011|author=Maleeha Lodhi|newspaper=alJazeera}}{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/asia/---Bonn-Conference-Offers-Few-Details-on-Supporting-Afghanistan-Past-2014-135103068.html|title=Bonn Conference Offers Few Details for Afghanistan Past 2014|newspaper=Voice of America|accessdate=22 December 2011|date=6 December 2011}} ===Revision of western-border rules of engagement=== {{See also|Pakistan–United States skirmishes}} Pakistan also strengthened its air defences and surveillance along the Afghanistan border as a precaution against any future incursions. DGMO Major General Ashaq Nadeem was quoted saying "We can expect more attacks from our supposed allies".{{cite news|title=Pak to deploy air defence weapons on Afghan border|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/303944/cabinet-and-senate-briefings-military-to-up-the-ante-on-western-front/|date=12 October 2011|author=Zia Khan|quote="We can expect more attacks from our supposed allies," Ahmed was quoted as saying during his briefing to the Senate panel. He also rejected claims by the US and NATO that the attack was unintended and the result of a misunderstanding.}} Pakistan's army chief General [[Ashfaq Parvez Kayani]] issued directions to commanders posted at the border to fire without permission if any further aggression is received.{{cite web |title=Pakistan has right to self-defence so does US: Pentagon |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/NewsDetail.aspx?ID=27840&title=Pak-has-right-to-self-defence-so-does-US |publisher=[[The News International]] |date=3 December 2011 |accessdate=3 December 2011}} According to a Pakistani security official, Pakistan had upgraded to a "fully equipped air defence system" on the Afghan border which has the capability of detecting, tracing and shooting down any aircraft.{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/304098/pakistan-upgrades-air-defences-on-afghan-border/|title=Pakistan upgrades air defences on Afghan border|work=Express Tribune|date=9 December 2011|accessdate=12 December 2011}} These weapons notably include indigenous shoulder-to-air [[Anza (missile)|Anza Mk-III]] missiles and [[anti-aircraft gun]]s.{{cite news|title=Spare no aggressor, Kayani told|url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/12/spare-no-aggressor-kayani-told/?printType=article|newspaper=Pakistan Today|date=10 December 2011|author=SHAIQ HUSSAIN}}{{cite news|title=Challenging Times for UAV Operations over Pakistan|url=http://defense-update.com/20111211_challenging-times-for-uav-operations-over-pakistan.html|newspaper=Defense Update}} The [[Pakistan Air Force]] cancelled leave for all its air [[reconnaissance]]-related personnel and deployed aircraft to start a round-the-clock [[combat air patrol]] over the Afghan border to prevent all intrusions including drone attacks.{{cite web|title=PAKISTAN DEPLOYS SHOULDER FIRED ANTI-AIRCRAFT MISSILES TO THE AFGHAN BORDER|url=http://aviationintel.com/?p=4420}}{{cite news|title=Pakistan boosts air defenses at Afghan border|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/upping-ante-pakistan-boosts-air-defenses-along-afghan-border/2011/12/09/gIQAgkPlhO_story_1.html|newspaper=The Washington Post | first=William|last=Wan|date=9 December 2011}} ==Reactions== {{main|NATO–Pakistan relations|Pakistan–United States relations}} The already fractured relationship between Pakistan and the United States fell to a new low following the incident, with the Pakistani government and military establishment reassessing their diplomatic, political, military and intelligence relationship with the United States.[https://news.yahoo.com/nato-attack-allegedly-kills-24-pakistani-troops-180926187.html NATO attack allegedly kills 24 Pakistani troops], Yahoo! News ===Reaction in Pakistan=== === Government and military === [[File:Syed Gillani - World Economic Forum on the Middle East 2008.jpg|thumb|Following the incident, Prime Minister Gillani called for a review of Pakistan's relationship with NATO and the United States.{{cite news|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/south-asia/pak-reassessing-relations-with-us-nato-gilani_746231.html|title=Pak reassessing relations with US, NATO: Gilani|work=Zee News|date=10 December 2011|accessdate=23 December 2011}}]] The [[Foreign Ministry of Pakistan]] promptly lodged a protest with [[United States Ambassador to Pakistan|US ambassador to Pakistan]] [[Cameron Munter]] following the attack. In an official phone call to the United States, Foreign Minister [[Hina Rabbani Khar]] said that the attacks demonstrated "complete disregard for international law and human life" and were "in stark violation of Pakistani sovereignty."{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/27/world/asia/pakistan-nato-attack/ |title=Pakistan: NATO attack inflames tense ties with U.S |publisher=CNN |accessdate=29 November 2011 |date=27 November 2011}} Sentiments within the Pakistani military leadership suggested the attack as being a pre-planned plot that was executed deliberately and intentionally.{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/pakistan/Pakistan-army-believes-NATO-attack-planned-says-reports/articleshow/11043774.cms |title=Pakistan army believes NATO attack planned says reports |work=Times of India |date=9 December 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120110111008/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/pakistan/Pakistan-army-believes-NATO-attack-planned-says-reports/articleshow/11043774.cms |archivedate=10 January 2012 }} Retired Brigadier Mahmood Shah, former chief of security in the tribal areas, said that so far the US has blamed Pakistan for all that is happening in Afghanistan and Pakistan's point of view has not been shown in the international media, so the matter should be taken up by the [[United Nations Security Council]]. He advised Pakistani authorities to shoot down NATO aircraft should a similar event take place in the future, and to keep the supply lines closed, on the argument that the US cannot afford a war with Pakistan.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2066488/U-S-helicopter-attack-killed-28-Pakistan-troops-act-self-defence.html |title=Pakistan gives US 2-week ultimatum to abandon 'secret' airbase and closes border | Mail Online |work=Daily Mail |location=UK |date=30 September 2009 |accessdate=29 November 2011}}{{cite news|last=Momand |first=Shams |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/26/us-pakistan-nato-idUSTRE7AP03S20111126 |title=Pakistan stops NATO supplies after deadly raid |publisher=Reuters |date=22 November 2011 |accessdate=29 November 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://oneclick.indiatimes.com/article/0fP57Qp4yI16Z?q=Afghanistan |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120718232109/http://oneclick.indiatimes.com/article/0fP57Qp4yI16Z?q=Afghanistan |archive-date=18 July 2012 |title=Pakistan demands U.S. vacate air base within 15 days |publisher=Oneclick.indiatimes.com |accessdate=29 November 2011 |deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/middle-east/6041277/Cross-border-NATO-raid-kills-up-to-14-Pakistani-troops |title=Cross-border raid kills 28 Pakistanis |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |accessdate=29 November 2011}}{{cite web|author=Staff |url=http://www.lhrtimes.com/2011/11/26/nato-helicopters-attack-on-pakistani-border-post-kills-25-soldiers/ |title=NATO helicopters attack on Pakistan border post kills 26 soldiers – The Lahore Times |publisher=Lhrtimes.com |date=26 November 2011 |accessdate=17 December 2011}} The [[Inter Services Public Relations]] (ISPR), a media wing of the Pakistani military, released a statement calling the attack unprovoked and said that chief of army staff, General [[Ashfaq Parvez Kayani]] had called the incident unacceptable and "directed that all necessary steps be under taken for an effective response to this irresponsible act".{{cite web|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=8375544&c=AIR&s=TOP |title=Pakistan Condemns 'Unprovoked' Border Attack |publisher=Defensenews.com |accessdate=29 November 2011}} One senior Pakistani military official said "the latest attack by NATO forces on our post will have serious repercussions as they, without any reasons, attacked on our post and killed soldiers asleep." The [[Senate of Pakistan|Pakistani Senate]] passed a unanimous resolution which denounced the attack and called it contrary to United Nations resolutions and international laws.{{cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/NewsDetail.aspx?ID=27795&title=Senate-passes-unanimous-resolution-to-condemn-NATO-attack|title=Senate passes unanimous resolution to condemn NATO attack|work=The News|date=3 December 2011|accessdate=7 December 2011}} Pakistan's Interior Minister [[Rehman Malik]] commented on the issue clarifying that the supply lines have not been suspended, rather been permanently shut down and the trucks would not be allowed to cross the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. The [[Minister of Information and Broadcasting (Pakistan)|Minister of Information and Broadcasting]] [[Firdous Ashiq Awan]] urged the international community to condemn the incident to prevent such incidents in the future.{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/209482/condemn-nato-attacks-pakistani-minister.html|title=Condemn NATO attacks, Pakistani minister tells world|work=Deccan Herald|date=5 December 2011|accessdate=7 December 2011}} The [[Governor of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Governor]] of [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Masood Kausar]], termed the air strike as "deliberate" and asserted that claims over the incident being accidental were untrue. He also blamed the instability in neighbouring Afghanistan as a cause of instability in Pakistan.{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/311613/nato-attack-was-deliberate-k-p-governor/|title=NATO attack was deliberate: K-P governor|work=Express Tribune|date=25 December 2011|accessdate=26 January 2012}} The televised funeral ceremony of the soldiers who died was held in [[Peshawar]] and was attended by several high-level military and political figures, including the Chief of Army Staff. Afterwards, their bodies were dispatched to their native towns for burial. The soldiers hailed from various regions, including three from [[Azad Kashmir]] alone, while the Major was from [[Larkana]] and the Captain from [[Sahiwal]]. Family members of Major Mujahid Mirani and Captain Usman Ali said the soldiers "sacrificed their lives" for the country and that they were proud of those sacrifices. The Army Chief later also paid a visit to the injured soldiers, who had been transported to the [[Combined Military Hospital]] (CMH) in Peshawar.{{cite web|author=AH Nizami / Manzoor Ali |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/298770/pakistan-buries-troops-amid-fury-over-nato-strike-2/ |title=Pakistan buries troops amid fury over NATO strike |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=29 November 2011}} On 28 November 2011, referring to Pak-US military, intelligence, political and diplomatic co-operation, the Pakistani Prime Minister announced that there would be no more business with the US and the relations between the two countries would never be the same again. Later the Director General of ISPR, Abbas, announced that NATO's apology was not accepted and the attack would have serious consequences. He said that NATO's regret over the attack was not enough and such incidents had happened in the past, killing 72 soldiers and injuring more than 250 troops in three years.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} While addressing a gathering of journalists at a military headquarters, Pakistan Army Major-General Ashfaq Nadeem described the Salala incident as a "deliberate act of aggression"{{cite news|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/world/2011/11/30/nato-attack-was-blatant-aggression-pakistan-army|title=NATO attack was blatant aggression: Pakistan army|work=[[Times Live]]|date=30 November 2011|accessdate=30 November 2011}} and said it was "next to impossible" that NATO did not know they were attacking Pakistani forces.[http://www.newser.com/article/d9raebf00/pakistan-to-boycott-key-meeting-in-germany-in-protest-over-nato-raid-that-killed-its-troops.html Pakistan to boycott key meeting in Germany in protest over NATO raid that killed its troops] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129141612/http://www.newser.com/article/d9raebf00/pakistan-to-boycott-key-meeting-in-germany-in-protest-over-nato-raid-that-killed-its-troops.html |date=29 November 2011 }}, Newser The next day, [[Permanent Representative of Pakistan to the United Nations|Pakistan's ambassador to the UN]], [[Hussain Haroon]] wrote to a letter to the UN Secretary General [[Ban Ki-moon]] to inform him of the situation and requested that the statement be forwarded to the 193-nation [[United Nations General Assembly|general assembly]] and the 15-nation [[United Nations Security Council|security council]] (UNSC) as a UNSC document.{{cite news|last=PTI|title=NATO attack: Pakistan writes to UN|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article2670703.ece|work=The Hindu |location=India|accessdate=29 November 2011|date=29 November 2011}} Commenting on drone attacks, a senior Pakistani official said that predator drones "will never be allowed back, at [[Shamsi Airbase|Shamsi]] or anywhere else" although he hinted that American military trainers may be allowed back into the country to train Pakistani security forces.{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/325020/us-military-trainers-allowed-but-not-drones-report/|title='US military trainers allowed, but not drones': Report|work=Express Tribune|date=21 January 2012|accessdate=22 January 2012}} Pakistan had previously dumped American security personnel out of the country, following a covert operation by US special forces that [[Death of Osama bin Laden|killed Osama bin Laden]] in the town of Abbottabad in May 2011 and strained Pakistan's relations with the United States. As of January 2012, foreign affairs minister Hina Rabbani Khar said Pakistan's ties with the United States were "still on hold" over the NATO air-attack and that until the re-evaluation was not complete, Washington could not ask Islamabad to pursue militant groups or assist in the Afghan peace process.{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/324091/relations-with-us-based-on-mutual-respect-interest-fo/|title=Pakistan-US ties still on hold over NATO attack: Khar|work=Express Tribune|date=19 January 2012|accessdate=22 January 2012}} {{Quote box |style="background:#FFFFF0;" |salign=center | quote = I would like the American public to consider what their reaction would have been if American troops had been killed in such an attack on their [[Mexico–United States border|border with Mexico]]. | source = —[[Bilawal Bhutto Zardari]], chairman of the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] | width = 33% | align = right }} In May 2012, [[Bilawal Bhutto Zardari]], son of President Zardari and chairman of the [[Pakistan Peoples Party]], toughened his stance when he called on President Obama to "show some courage" and "apologise to Pakistan" over the raid. Ridiculing US demands for Islamabad to "do more" in the Afghanistan war, Bilawal remarked "it is time for the US to do more". He called US drone operations a "constant irritant" to Pakistani public opinion and questioned whether the United States "actually considered Pakistan a military ally", citing other controversial events such as the Abbottabad operation and the [[Raymond Davis incident]]. He also remarked that while he understood Obama was facing a re-election, "the future of the NATO mission in Afghanistan should be more important than poll numbers".{{cite news|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/national/23-May-2012/obama-should-apologise-for-salala-attack-bilawal|title=Obama should apologise for Salala attack: Bilawal|work=The Nation|date=23 May 2012|accessdate=26 May 2012}} === Opposition political parties === {{Quote box |style="background:#FFFFF0;" |salign=center | quote = I know that the government will not do anything except issue some silly comments against brutality even after this attack. I do not issue comments, I believe in taking action. | source = —[[Imran Khan]], leader of the [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] | width = 33% | align = right }} A [[PML (N)]] politician remarked that the government's incompetence had allowed the attack to be carried out. [[Imran Khan]], a popular opposition politician and former [[cricketer]] who has been a long-time staunch critic of the government's foreign policy and its decision to join the American-led War on Terror, called the attack unpardonable{{cite web|url=http://www.dawn.com/2011/11/27/nato-attack-widely-condemned-in-khyber-pakhtunkhwa-2.html |title=Nato attack widely condemned in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa |publisher=Dawn.com |accessdate=29 November 2011}} during a political rally in [[Multan]], and said the Pakistani government had wasted $70 billion belonging to the Pakistani people, as well as [[List of terrorist incidents in Pakistan since 2001|the lives of 40,000 people]], on fighting a counter-productive American war: "I know that the government will not do anything except issue some silly comments against brutality even after this attack. I do not issue comments, I believe in taking action."{{cite web|last=Jaffery |first=Owais |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/298167/imran-khans-i-have-a-dream-speech/ |title=Imran Khan's 'I have a dream' speech |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |accessdate=29 November 2011}} An [[Awami National Party]] politician and senator called the incident a terrorist attack. [[Awami Muslim League (Pakistan)|Awami Muslim League]] party leader [[Sheikh Rashid Ahmed]] supported a blockade of NATO supplies "to teach an unforgettable lesson to USA and NATO forces for violating Pakistani soil." [[Muttahida Qaumi Movement|MQM]] chief [[Altaf Hussain (Pakistani politician)|Altaf Hussain]] condemned the attack and directed his party to observe a "Stability and Solidarity Day". Former president [[Pervez Musharraf]] heavily criticised the attack while giving a telephonic conference to the [[Karachi Press Club]] and advised the government to take strict measures at a diplomatic level.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2011%5C12%5C02%5Cstory_2-12-2011_pg7_8 |title=Musharraf slams NATO attack, vows to return in March |work=Daily Times |date=2 December 2011 |accessdate=2 December 2011 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120729042835/http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2011%5C12%5C02%5Cstory_2-12-2011_pg7_8 |archivedate=July 29, 2012}} Many other leaders also called on the government to pull out of the war in Afghanistan and disassociate itself from the U.S. alliance. The [[Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam|JUI]] called the attack a "shameful incident" and "a slap across the face of Pakistani foreign policy" adopted by rulers who "always bow before their foreign masters."{{cite web|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/NewsDetail.aspx?ID=27348&title=JUI-condemns-NATO-attack,-demands-independent-foreign-policy |title=JUI condemns NATO attack, demands independent foreign policy |publisher=Thenews.com.pk |accessdate=29 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111128004239/http://www.thenews.com.pk/NewsDetail.aspx?ID=27348&title=JUI-condemns-NATO-attack%2C-demands-independent-foreign-policy |archivedate=28 November 2011 |df= }} Protesters affiliated with the right-wing [[Jamaat-ud-Dawa]] held a rally outside the [[Lahore Press Club]] where they urged the [[Pakistan Army]] to give a "befitting response" to NATO; the leader of the party said "We have to eliminate all stations and bases given to the CIA if we want to end terrorism in Pakistan". === Public and media === {{ external media | align = right | width = | image1 = [https://fbcdn-sphotos-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/374612_251205521600933_109463862441767_594088_1876508214_n.jpg Maj. Mujahid and Capt. Usman],{{cite news|title=A Recent Photograph of Major Mujahid and Captain Usman|url=http://www.pakistantime.net/2011/11/a-recent-photograph-of-major-mujahid-and-captain-usman/|date=29 November 2011}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The two commanders of the post killed in the attack. | image2 =
